pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
This all looks good to me!  I left a few comments.

Also, thank you for dealing with the sign change on the exponents: that wrinkle was not something I was looking forward to iron out, but you found a very sneaky way to do it!
This looks good to me!  Thanks!

:v: ocfnash can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  Build succeeded!

  The publicly hosted instance of bors-ng is deprecated and will go away soon.

  If you want to self-host your own instance, [instructions are here][instructions].
  For more help, visit [the forum].

  If you want to switch to GitHub's built-in merge queue, visit [their help page][gh].

  [instructions]: https://github.com/bors-ng/bors-ng#how-to-set-up-your-own-real-instance
  [the forum]: https://forum.bors.tech
  [gh]: https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/configuring-branches-and-merges-in-your-repository/configuring-pull-request-merges/managing-a-merge-queue



  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/5825475765/job/15797128552)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/5825475765/job/15797128730)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/5825475765/job/15797128856)
A couple of extra really minor comments!
bors d+
Is this meaningfully different from `LeftRegular.pow` (if that exists)? Should we have an `IsRightZeroDivisor` predicate to make this easier to parse?

This is not quite the same as the concept arising from `IsRightRegular` though it is in the presence of a `Ring` structure. To be precise:
```lean
example {R : Type _} [Ring R] {x : R} :
    IsRightRegular x ↔ ∀ y, y * x = 0 → y = 0 := by
-- Proof omitted
```
However I have now dropped these rather cumbersome lemmas by introducing `nonZeroDivisorsLeft` and relying on `Submonoid.pow_mem` instead.
This would be nice to state as `RightRegular (X^n)` (which is defeq) or similar
I think that `Polynomial.Monic.isRegular` exists as well.

Looking at `Polynomial.Monic.isRegular` I think that the proof uses subtractions, whereas the result should be true for semirings.  In fact, assuming that the leading coefficient is regular should be enough.  The proof should go via Polynomial.coeff_mul_degree_add_degree.

Just to make my suggestion be concrete
```suggestion
theorem X_pow_isRegular (n : ℕ) : IsRegular (X ^ n) := by
```
from which this result and the symmetric one is a single projection away (`.left` and ` .right`)

Thanks, I'll adjust.

Note incidentally that I'm only adding this to fill an API hole since `mul_X_pow_injective` already exists. (I will of course also adjust this also.)
Done.
Btw, my comment about is wrong: I confused `IsRegular` with not being a zero-divisor.  To atone, I PRed a counterexample: #6476.

```suggestion
This file is a place for results related to nilpotency in (single-variable) polynomial rings.
```
Just a typo.
Thanks!

Let me try again: I think that more generally, the product of any two non right zero divisors is a non right zero divisor.  That is, the set of non right zero divisors is a semigroup.

Unless I am still confused, the proof is just associativity and application twice of the non-zero divisor hypothesis.

This is a great suggestion. I have dropped these lemmas an instead proposed introducing `nonZeroDivisorsLeft` and `nonZeroDivisorsRight` so that I can get this result via `Submonoid.pow_mem` which is essentially what you're suggesting. Thanks!
I think that `pow` and `X` should be swapped and also that `Polynomial.coeff_X_pow` exists, right?
I think we're a bit inconsistent about naming when we have infix notation like this (I would argue `coeff_pow_X` is "more correct") but in any case you're right: we already have this lemma. Thanks!
I'm reviewing on mobile, so I may be misunderstanding.  NoZeroDivisors implies in particular that only `0` is nilpotent, right?
Absolutely, this was a thinko on my part, caused by mechanical generalisation.

```suggestion
  exact ⟨(hb ·), fun ha ↦ by rw [ha, mul_zero]⟩
```
if you are into this sort of syntax!
I like the idea but in this case I think the suggestion makes this slightly harder to read.
Technically, this probably makes sense for `SemigroupWithZero` and `Subsemigroup` as well...

It does but I need the `Submonoid` type since I want to use `Submonoid.pow_mem` (which cannot exist for `Subsemigroup` because the power might be zero).

We could of course make both definitions but I propose waiting since we do not have an application in mind.

Sure, it just got me thinking about whether I had ever encountered a ring without unit and with nilpotent elements, but I could not come up with one.  Likely, because I do not often see rings without units!  :smile:

nit (untested):
```suggestion
theorem isRegular_X_pow (n : ℕ) : IsRegular (X ^ n : R[X]) := by
```
While we are on the topic, @eric-wieser, what do you think of `(X (R := R) ^ n)`?
I think that's worse
I agree with Eric here and have made this suggestion.
I guess you can probably prove these in the other direction and use `isRegular_X.pow n`?
OK I've made this change but it doesn't really affect anything because of the existing API for polynomials.
Update: looking at the diff now, I do prefer the new version (using `IsRegular.pow`).
nit: big operator notation?
Thanks, done.

```suggestion
theorem isRegular_X_pow (n : ℕ) : IsRegular (X ^ n : R[X]) := isRegular_X.pow n
```

Untested
```suggestion
  mul_mem' {x} {y} hx hy := fun z hz ↦ hx _ <| hy _ (mul_assoc z x y ▸ hz)
```
Could you add the lemma that the two submonoids are equal in commutative monoids with zero?
Isn't there already an `α` around?
Can you add the `PredOrder` version too, or is it not trivially true via the OrderDual?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: lemmas about nilpotency and polynomials
